item.title: Reconstruction Official Resigns, Highlighting Tensions in Ukraine
item.description: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s top official for the reconstruction of the war-torn east resigned on Tuesday, citing a lack of support from the government and a failure to secure funding for projects to rebuild the region.

item.title: Buoyed by Election, Meloni Basks in Spotlight as Italy Hosts G7
item.description: By Giada Zampano July 6, 2023 ROME — Giorgia Meloni, Italy’s first female prime minister, basked in the international spotlight on Thursday as she welcomed leaders from the Group of Seven nations to the ancient coastal town of Syracuse, Sicily, for a summit that was expected to focus on energy security, the global economy and China.

item.title: France in Shock as Conservative Leader Embraces Far Right
item.description: By JAMES KANTER and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA PARIS — François Fillon, the conservative candidate for the French presidency, has been a champion of the free market, a critic of the European Union and a defender of the French language.

item.title: Iran Names Six Candidates for President, Including Parliament Speaker
item.description: Iran’s Guardian Council, a body of clerics and jurists, has approved six candidates for the country’s presidential election on June 18, including the incumbent, Hassan Rouhani, and the parliament speaker, Ali Larijani.

item.title: Modi, Striking a Modest Tone, Is Sworn In for a Third Term
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi was sworn in for a third term on Thursday, promising to work for the “poor, the downtrodden and the marginalized” as he took the oath of office in a ceremony that was scaled back because of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Flemish Nationalists Thwart Ascent of Secessionist Party in Belgian Elections
item.description: By J. D. Longstreet The Flemish Nationalists, in Belgium, have thwarted the ascent of a secessionist party in the Belgian elections. The Flemish Nationalists, who are the largest party in the Flemish region of Belgium, have been able to keep the secessionist party, the New Flemish Alliance (N-VA), from gaining a majority in the Flemish parliament.

item.title: Mexico’s Leftists Won Big. Investors Are Worried.
item.description: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and ALEXANDER BURNS MEXICO CITY — The leftist Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador won Mexico’s presidential election on Sunday, a victory that could upend the country’s economic policies and shift its foreign relations, particularly with the United States.

item.title: Battered by Far Right in E.U. Vote, Macron Calls for New Elections in France
item.description: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron of France called on Saturday for new parliamentary elections to be held in June, after his party suffered a crushing defeat in the European Parliament elections, with the far right making significant gains.

item.title: In E.U. Elections, the Center Holds, but the Far Right Still Wreaks Havoc
item.description: The European Union’s parliamentary elections, held last week, were a test of the bloc’s resilience in the face of populist and nationalist movements. The results, while not a complete repudiation of the far right, were a clear rejection of the most extreme voices.

item.title: The E.U. Is Voting. It’s Never Mattered More.
item.description: The European Union is holding its first-ever direct elections for the European Parliament. The results will determine the direction of the 27-nation bloc for the next five years.

item.title: A War on the Nile Pushes Sudan Toward the Abyss
item.description: A War on the Nile Pushes Sudan Toward the Abyss Sudanese soldiers stand guard at a checkpoint in the capital, Khartoum, on June 16, 2021. Mohamed Nureldin Abdallah/Reuters

item.title: In Global Elections, Strongmen Are Taken Down a Notch
item.description: The world is witnessing a wave of elections in which strongmen are being challenged, and in some cases, defeated. In the United States, President Donald Trump, who has been accused of authoritarian tendencies, is facing a tough re-election battle against former Vice President Joe Biden.

item.title: Needing Help to Stay in Power, Modi Loses His Aura of Invincibility
item.description: By Rakesh Raman Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who was once considered invincible, is now struggling to stay in power. Modi, who is known for his aggressive and autocratic style of governance, is facing a tough challenge from the opposition parties in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh (UP) where he is trying to win the assembly elections to be held in February 2017.

item.title: Rival U.K. Political Leaders Clash in Bad-Tempered Election Debate
item.description: LONDON—Britain’s two main political leaders clashed in a bad-tempered debate Thursday, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson accusing his Labour Party rival Jeremy Corbyn of being a Marxist who would wreck the economy and the opposition leader saying the Conservative leader was a liar.

item.title: Modi Struggles to Stay on Top> 4 Takeaways From India’s Election
item.description: India’s ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) is struggling to maintain its majority in the country’s parliament, according to exit polls released Sunday. The polls suggest that the BJP will win between 151 and 206 seats in the 543-seat Lok Sabha, the lower house of India’s parliament, falling short of the 272 seats needed for a majority.

item.title: For Heroes of D-Day, This Reunion Might Be a ‘Last Hurrah’
item.description: By JAMES BARRON Published: June 6, 2014 OMAHA BEACH, France — The men who stormed the beaches of Normandy 70 years ago are getting old, and many are dying.

item.title: A Surging Hard Right in Europe Stumbles Over Its Own Divisions
item.description: The European Union is facing a crisis of legitimacy, with the rise of populist, nationalist parties that are challenging the very foundations of the bloc. These parties, which have gained significant ground in recent years, are united by their opposition to immigration, their skepticism of globalization, and their rejection of the EU’s institutions and values.

item.title: Another Milestone in Mexico> Its First Jewish President
item.description: By: Yair Rosenberg On July 1, 2018, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, a left-wing populist, was sworn in as the president of Mexico. He is the first Jewish president in the country’s history.

item.title: Jacob Zuma Gets His Revenge on South African Party That Shunned Him
item.description: Jacob Zuma, the former president of South Africa, has been a polarizing figure since he took office in 2009. His tenure was marked by allegations of corruption, economic mismanagement, and a disregard for the rule of law.

item.title: Netanyahu May Face a Choice Between a Truce and His Government’s Survival
item.description: Netanyahu May Face a Choice Between a Truce and His Government’s Survival Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is facing a difficult choice: whether to accept a ceasefire with Hamas or risk the collapse of his government.
